subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_00AB_01C9D162.F6BE32F0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Exactly-ALWAYS save the original of everything. That way you can always go =
back.

Have a great day!

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Misty Daw=
n 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 11:26 AM
  S=
ubject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules





        Which is why its al=
ways good to have the original to fall back on saved in better format. A bi=
t like "can't see the flowers for the trees" it depends on what viewpoint y=
ou take as to what you see/hear or believe. 

        Ok gotta split like a=
n atom or I will be late =3D)

        Misty


        --- On Sun, 5/10/09,=
 April Abercrombie <april@...> wrote:


          =
From: April Abercrombie <april@...>
          Subj=
ect: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.c=
om
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:12 PM


          This is why wi=
th digital photos, you can't enlarge them without loosing resolution. You c=
an go smaller, but not larger.

          When you enlarge a digital photo,=
 the photo gets stretched, but the same amount of pixels have to now fill i=
n, so they get larger, which magnifies the pixelation. You end up with a bl=
ocky "lo-res" image. You can choose to have it "resample", but then you get=
 what RJ described, where the program looks at the existing pixels and add =
pixels that are an average of the surrounding pixels. So you still end up w=
hat a grainy, digital looking picture.

          When saving a photo to a =
compressed format, such as jpeg, you actually loose data, or pixels. The pr=
ogram decides which data to drop to make the file smaller. Each time you op=
en and resave, you loose more data.The resolution gets worse and worse.

  =
        This is the same thing that happens with audio files, you loose dat=
a each time you save it to a compressed format.

            ----- Original=
 Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .=
com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
            Subject: R=
e: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                  Pixelization doesn't=
 clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field of=
 flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soon=
, you would not be able to tell there were flowers there at all.  You would=
 see a lot of colored blocks.

                  Or in the other direction,=
 imagine you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your sc=
reen: a complete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, aft=
er a while, you would again start to see colored blocks.

                 =
 What's happening is that it is processing an area of the image, taking (fo=
r instance) the average value of that entire area, and replacing all the bl=
ocks in that area with the average.  In video processing, this would result=
 in a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big=
 greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise exampl=
e, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish b=
lock.  If you did not know beforehand what the original picture was, you co=
uldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a c=
hevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

                  =
It works the same with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as spe=
ech, and replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the fa=
rther you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the s=
ame to random static will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fl=
uctuating square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could=
 have fun sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





  =
                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wr=
ote:


                    From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
      =
              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                 =
   To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2=
009, 9:29 AM


                          I always save the whole file in wa=
v format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

=
                          As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise =
whos to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a for=
m of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes=
/film, no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all =
interesting.

                          Just a thought. Ok off to work now!=

                          Misty

                          --- On Sun, 5/1=
0/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                            From: R=
j <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules
                            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .c=
om
                            Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


     =
                           Be a bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are =
doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.   While some formats (like =
wav) can store the audio very close to the way it was recorded, formats lik=
e mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic details.  T=
his may not be a big deal in music, where the audio is fairly clear to begi=
n with.  But with sound sources with a lot of noise (like evps), this can n=
ot only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise)=
 and make them start to sound like speech.

                               =
 So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, once you've already formed an o=
pinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medi=
um for analysis.  It can lead to many false positives and misinterpretation=
s.

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bullet=
babea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn=
 <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP=
-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yaho=
ogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:=
26 AM


                                Thanks =3D)

                      =
           You will get the hang of it. Kristen is right thats how you save=
 it. For most softwares its under save as or export as. If you still have t=
rouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.

                     =
           Misty

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Snow=
fireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:


                              =
  From: SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol. com>
                           =
     Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                          =
      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Su=
nday, May 10, 2009, 2:14 AM


                                Ok, Misty I'l=
l take them out, this recording stuff is new to me.

                      =
          In a message dated 5/10/2009 1:13:01 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time, =
bulletbabea@ yahoo.com writes:



                                Please do=
 not upload wav format files here they will have to be removed. Our group o=
nly has a very limited amount of space. Upload bigger files and mass amount=
 of files to your esnips.com accounts or elsewhere to be shared here using =
links. 

                                Misty

                           =
     --- On Sat, 5/9/09, EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com <EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com=
> wrote:

yahoogroups .com

9, 11:50 PM

                    =
            This email message is a notification to let you know that

e EVP-ITC 
                                group.

                        =
        File : /Snowfirel/test1sou nds_like_ three_squeeking_ words.wav

                                Description : Test1 these are last 3 words=
, can't make them out, haven't changed anything on this one tape from last =
night aprox. 8 p. the whole tape with my mom on it was around 4 minutes lon=
g, seems like these folks on the other side have a lot to say in a short ti=
me. 

                                You can access this file at the URL:
=
                                http://groups. yahoo.com/ group/EVP- ITC/fi=
les/ Snowfirel/ test1sounds_ like_three_ squeeking_ words.wav 

           =
                     To learn more about file sharing for your group, pleas=
e visit:
                                http://help. yahoo.com/ l/us/yahoo=
/ groups/original/ members/web/ index.htmlfiles

                          =
      Regards,

                                snowfirel <SnowfireL@aol. c=
om>
